title: Who first said “No matter where you go there you are?” - Quora

response.answer_text: “No matter where you go, there you are.” The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension (motion picture) (1984).  There is also a song which includes the line, This song is by Luka Bloom and appears on the album Innocence (2005). As every true Blue Blaze Irregular knows, it was Buckaroo Banzai. Probably in an adventure involving time travel, so no matter who originated the saying, Buckaroo was the first person in history to say it. …and in the real world, we don't actually know. I've seen it attributed to Confucius, but the phrase in question is also translated as “Wherever you go, go with all your heart” which has a rather different meaning. I've also seen a claim that the phrase was used in the 1950s by Alcoholics Anonymous. It is apparently a summary of an AA Big Book story about how moving to a new place doesn't leave your internal problems behind. But I can't find any actual references to which story it is, or how early it was summarized into that phrase, or even if the phrase had that exact wording. So the earliest verified source I can find is Earl Mac Rauch, screenwriter of “The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai Across the 8th Dimension.” He originated the character sometime in the late 1970s, and started writing the actual screenplay in 1980, four years before the movie's release. I doubt that the phrase is really original with Rauch; in fact I wouldn't be surprised to find multiple independent origins for a saying like that. He's just the earliest that I can verify.
